I remember a "magic with chemistry" show when I was young, in which the demonstrator soaked a cigar in liquid O2 and then lit it. It burned like a flare.

In another demo, a wad of foam rubber was stuffed into a metal tube which was closed on one end, then soaked with liquid O2 then ignited. The foam did a mild explosion and burst out of the tube... fun stuff. Unfortunately when the same demo was done a few years later, the tube shattered, sending shards of metal flying. One youngster in the front row of the auditorium was hit in the eye, IIRC. One might speculate that when the metal was supercooled it became brittle, and years of being used for that demo left it cracked and weakened. That particular item was removed from future "magic with chemistry" shows.

Nice video. You should have purged the test tube with oxygen prior to cooling it down since you will have condensed any residual water vapor in the air that was trapped in the tube prior. As a side note, this can lead to a dangerous situation in the lab when you are working with vacuum and a trap. You should never cool your trap prior to turning on vacuum since you can condense liquid oxygen in the trap. The trap will have grease and generally you are pulling off organics into the trap. Your previous video on oxygen generation shows what happens when you mix pure oxygen and hydrocarbon. This has led to many explosions in labs in university settings.

Well, if you raise the temperature and the pressure too much, densities of both liquid and gaseous phases will approximate each other and finally build a single supercritical phase. A supercritical gas cannot be liquified by rising the pressure and a supercritical liquid cannot be vaporized by rising the temperature. In both cases, a supercritical fluid is formed. And helium is the only substance that cannot be solidified at noraml pressure and is liquid at absolute zero.

0:17 - "...but if we increase pressure enough or lower the temperature enough we can put it back into a liquid" - well, if a substance is above it's critical point you can't "put it back" into a liquid, no matter how much pressure you'll exert. Sorry, I just have to point this out. You may feel slightly embarrassed. I quite often buy liquid nitrogen and play with it and sometimes I make liquid oxygen with it. But, did you know you can make liquid oxygen by just taking a beaker of liquid nitrogen and placing an empty test tube in it? That's it! No need for that fancy apparatus. The ONLY issue is you will get a tiny piece, or two, of solid H2O / CO2 in your liquid O2. But that can EASILY be separated by physical means in 2 seconds. To make it super fast, I would place a few test tubes in the container of LN2 and then pour all the liquid O2 into a single test tube.

EDIT: ahhh the liquid argon you might ask? let the liquid boil for a second after removing the test tube from the liquid nitrogen and BOOM, pure liquid oxygen.

Fun scientific fact: the borosilicate beaker didn't actually break from the heat, since borosilicate is the commonly used type of glass for chemistry sets, because of it's high resistance to really high temperatures and really low temperatures. The thing that actually broke the glass was the glass itself contracting from the extreme cold of the liquid oxygen, only to be very rapidly heated by the molten steel from the steel wool. The different forces pulling different ways caused ruptures at the molecular level, causing a chain reaction that led to the bottom of the glass shattering.

Your description of paramagnetism isn't quite right. You're conflating paramagnetic/ferromagnetic with the presence of hysteresis. They're different things.

Plenty of ferromagnets do not retain magnetization once the external field is removed, but are still ferromagnets.

Rather, the fundamental difference is that in a ferromagnet the response is much stronger because it is energetically favorable for the atoms in large chunks of the material to align their magnetic moments together in the presence of an external field. In a paramagnet, this is not the case, and so you only get a small amount of induced magnetization (you can calculate how much with a simple Boltzmann factor).
